questions.question: If $f(x) = \begin{vmatrix} a & -1 & 0 \\ ax & a & -1 \\ ax^2 & ax & a \end{vmatrix}$, using properties of determinants find the value of $f(2x) - f(x)$.
questions.solution:
Apply $R_2 \to R_2 - xR_1$ and $R_3 \to R_3 - x^2R_1$:
$$f(x) = \begin{vmatrix} a & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & a+x & -1 \\ 0 & ax+x^2 & a \end{vmatrix}$$
Expanding along the first column:
$$f(x) = a\bigl[(a+x)(a) - (-1)(ax + x^2)\bigr] = a(a^2 + ax + ax + x^2) = a(a+x)^2$$
Therefore:
$$f(2x) - f(x) = a(2x+a)^2 - a(x+a)^2 = a\bigl[(2x+a)^2 - (x+a)^2\bigr]$$
$$= a(2x+a+x+a)(2x+a-x-a) = a(3x+2a)(x) = ax(3x+2a)$$

questions.question: Find: $\displaystyle\int \frac{dx}{\sin x + \sin 2x}$
questions.solution:
$$\int \frac{dx}{\sin x + \sin 2x} = \int \frac{dx}{\sin x(1 + 2\cos x)} = \int \frac{\sin x\, dx}{(1-\cos x)(1+\cos x)(1+2\cos x)}$$
Let $\cos x = t$, so $-\sin x\, dx = dt$:
$$= -\int \frac{dt}{(1-t)(1+t)(1+2t)}$$
Using partial fractions:
$$\frac{-1}{(1-t)(1+t)(1+2t)} = \frac{-1/6}{1-t} + \frac{1/2}{1+t} - \frac{4/3}{1+2t}$$
Integrating:
$$= \frac{1}{6}\log|1-t| + \frac{1}{2}\log|1+t| - \frac{2}{3}\log|1+2t| + C$$
$$= \frac{1}{6}\log|1-\cos x| + \frac{1}{2}\log|1+\cos x| - \frac{2}{3}\log|1+2\cos x| + C$$

alternativeQuestion.question: Integrate the following with respect to $x$: $\dfrac{x^2 - 3x + 1}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}$
alternativeQuestion.solution:
$$\int \frac{x^2-3x+1}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}\,dx = \int \frac{2-3x-(1-x^2)}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}\,dx$$
$$= 2\int \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}\,dx - 3\int \frac{x}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}\,dx - \int \sqrt{1-x^2}\,dx$$
Computing each integral:
$$= 2\sin^{-1}x + 3\sqrt{1-x^2} - \frac{x}{2}\sqrt{1-x^2} - \frac{1}{2}\sin^{-1}x + C$$
$$= \frac{3}{2}\sin^{-1}x + \frac{1}{2}(6-x)\sqrt{1-x^2} + C$$

questions.question: Evaluate: $\displaystyle\int_{-\pi}^{\pi} (\cos ax - \sin bx)^2\, dx$
questions.solution:
$$I = \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} (\cos ax - \sin bx)^2\,dx = \int_{-\pi}^{\pi}(\cos^2 ax + \sin^2 bx)\,dx - \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} 2\cos ax\sin bx\,dx$$
$$= I_1 - I_2$$
Since $\cos^2 ax + \sin^2 bx$ is an even function:
$$I_1 = 2\int_0^{\pi}(\cos^2 ax + \sin^2 bx)\,dx$$
Since $2\cos ax \sin bx$ is an odd function:
$$I_2 = 0$$
Therefore:
$$I = I_1 = \int_0^{\pi}(1+\cos 2ax + 1 - \cos 2bx)\,dx$$
$$= \left[2x + \frac{\sin 2ax}{2a} - \frac{\sin 2bx}{2b}\right]_0^{\pi}$$
$$= 2\pi + \frac{1}{2a}\sin 2a\pi - \frac{\sin 2b\pi}{2b}$$

questions.question: A bag A contains 4 black and 6 red balls and bag B contains 7 black and 3 red balls. A die is thrown. If 1 or 2 appears on it, then bag A is chosen, otherwise bag B. If two balls are drawn at random (without replacement) from the selected bag, find the probability of one of them being red and another black.
questions.solution:
Let $E_1$: selecting bag A, $E_2$: selecting bag B.
$$P(E_1) = \frac{1}{3}, \quad P(E_2) = \frac{2}{3}$$
Let $A$: getting one red and one black ball.
$$P(A|E_1) = \frac{{}^4C_1 \cdot {}^6C_1}{{}^{10}C_2} = \frac{24}{45} = \frac{8}{15}$$
$$P(A|E_2) = \frac{{}^7C_1 \cdot {}^3C_1}{{}^{10}C_2} = \frac{21}{45} = \frac{7}{15}$$
By the law of total probability:
$$P(A) = P(E_1)\cdot P(A|E_1) + P(E_2)\cdot P(A|E_2)$$
$$= \frac{1}{3}\cdot\frac{8}{15} + \frac{2}{3}\cdot\frac{7}{15} = \frac{8}{45} + \frac{14}{45} = \frac{22}{45}$$

questions.question: If $\vec{r} = x\hat{i} + y\hat{j} + z\hat{k}$, find $(\vec{r} \times \hat{i})\cdot(\vec{r} \times \hat{j}) + xy$.
questions.solution:
$$\vec{r} \times \hat{i} = (x\hat{i}+y\hat{j}+z\hat{k})\times\hat{i} = -y\hat{k} + z\hat{j}$$
$$\vec{r} \times \hat{j} = (x\hat{i}+y\hat{j}+z\hat{k})\times\hat{j} = x\hat{k} - z\hat{i}$$
Therefore:
$$(\vec{r}\times\hat{i})\cdot(\vec{r}\times\hat{j}) = (0\hat{i}+z\hat{j}-y\hat{k})\cdot(-z\hat{i}+0\hat{j}+x\hat{k})$$
$$= 0 + 0 + (-y)(x) = -xy$$
Hence:
$$(\vec{r}\times\hat{i})\cdot(\vec{r}\times\hat{j}) + xy = -xy + xy = 0$$

questions.question: Find the distance between the point $(-1,\,-5,\,-10)$ and the point of intersection of the line $\dfrac{x-2}{3} = \dfrac{y+1}{4} = \dfrac{z-2}{12}$ and the plane $x - y + z = 5$.
questions.solution:
Any point on the line is $(3\lambda+2,\; 4\lambda-1,\; 12\lambda+2)$.
Substituting into the plane $x - y + z = 5$:
$$(3\lambda+2) - (4\lambda-1) + (12\lambda+2) = 5$$
$$11\lambda + 5 = 5 \implies \lambda = 0$$
Point of intersection: $(2,\,-1,\,2)$.
Required distance:
$$= \sqrt{(2-(-1))^2 + (-1-(-5))^2 + (2-(-10))^2}$$
$$= \sqrt{9 + 16 + 144} = \sqrt{169} = 13$$

questions.question: If $\sin\!\left[\cot^{-1}(x+1)\right] = \cos(\tan^{-1}x)$, then find $x$.
questions.solution:
Writing:
$$\cot^{-1}(x+1) = \sin^{-1}\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+(x+1)^2}}, \qquad \tan^{-1}x = \cos^{-1}\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+x^2}}$$
So the equation becomes:
$$\sin\!\left(\sin^{-1}\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+(x+1)^2}}\right) = \cos\!\left(\cos^{-1}\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+x^2}}\right)$$
$$\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+(x+1)^2}} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1+x^2}}$$
$$1 + x^2 + 2x + 1 = 1 + x^2 \implies 2x + 1 = 0 \implies x = -\frac{1}{2}$$

alternativeQuestion.question: If $(\tan^{-1}x)^2 + (\cot^{-1}x)^2 = \dfrac{5\pi^2}{8}$, then find $x$.
alternativeQuestion.solution:
Using $\cot^{-1}x = \dfrac{\pi}{2} - \tan^{-1}x$:
$$(\tan^{-1}x)^2 + \left(\frac{\pi}{2}-\tan^{-1}x\right)^2 = \frac{5\pi^2}{8}$$
$$2(\tan^{-1}x)^2 - \pi\tan^{-1}x - \frac{3\pi^2}{8} = 0$$
Let $u = \tan^{-1}x$:
$$\tan^{-1}x = \frac{\pi \pm \sqrt{\pi^2 + 3\pi^2}}{4} = \frac{\pi \pm 2\pi}{4}$$
This gives $\tan^{-1}x = \dfrac{3\pi}{4}$ or $\tan^{-1}x = -\dfrac{\pi}{4}$.
Since $\tan^{-1}x \in \left(-\dfrac{\pi}{2},\dfrac{\pi}{2}\right)$, we take $\tan^{-1}x = -\dfrac{\pi}{4}$, giving $x = -1$.

questions.question: If $y = \tan^{-1}\!\left(\dfrac{\sqrt{1+x^2}+\sqrt{1-x^2}}{\sqrt{1+x^2}-\sqrt{1-x^2}}\right)$, $x^2 \le 1$, then find $\dfrac{dy}{dx}$.
questions.solution:
Put $x^2 = \cos\theta$:
$$y = \tan^{-1}\!\left(\frac{\sqrt{1+\cos\theta}+\sqrt{1-\cos\theta}}{\sqrt{1+\cos\theta}-\sqrt{1-\cos\theta}}\right)$$
$$= \tan^{-1}\!\left(\frac{\cos\tfrac{\theta}{2}+\sin\tfrac{\theta}{2}}{\cos\tfrac{\theta}{2}-\sin\tfrac{\theta}{2}}\right) = \tan^{-1}\!\left(\frac{1+\tan\tfrac{\theta}{2}}{1-\tan\tfrac{\theta}{2}}\right)$$
$$= \tan^{-1}\!\left(\tan\!\left(\frac{\pi}{4}+\frac{\theta}{2}\right)\right) = \frac{\pi}{4}+\frac{\theta}{2} = \frac{\pi}{4}+\frac{1}{2}\cos^{-1}x^2$$
Differentiating:
$$\frac{dy}{dx} = -\frac{1}{2}\cdot\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^4}}\cdot 2x = -\frac{x}{\sqrt{1-x^4}}$$

questions.question: If $x = a\cos\theta + b\sin\theta$, $y = a\sin\theta - b\cos\theta$, show that $y^2\dfrac{d^2y}{dx^2} - x\dfrac{dy}{dx} + y = 0$.
questions.solution:
$$\frac{dx}{d\theta} = -a\sin\theta + b\cos\theta, \qquad \frac{dy}{d\theta} = a\cos\theta + b\sin\theta$$
$$\frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{dy/d\theta}{dx/d\theta} = \frac{a\cos\theta+b\sin\theta}{-a\sin\theta+b\cos\theta} = -\frac{x}{y}$$
So:
$$y\frac{dy}{dx} + x = 0$$
Differentiating with respect to $x$:
$$y\frac{d^2y}{dx^2} + \frac{dy}{dx}\cdot\frac{dy}{dx} + 1 = 0$$
Multiplying through by $y$:
$$y^2\frac{d^2y}{dx^2} + \left(\frac{dy}{dx}\right)^2 y + y = 0$$
Since $\dfrac{dy}{dx} = -\dfrac{x}{y}$, we get $y\cdot\left(\dfrac{dy}{dx}\right)^2 = \dfrac{x^2}{y}$. Substituting back:
$$y^2\frac{d^2y}{dx^2} - x\frac{dy}{dx} + y = 0 \qquad \blacksquare$$

questions.question: The side of an equilateral triangle is increasing at the rate of 2 cm/s. At what rate is its area increasing when the side of the triangle is 20 cm?
questions.solution:
Let $x$ be the side of the equilateral triangle. Given $\dfrac{dx}{dt} = 2$ cm/s.
Area:
$$A = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}x^2$$
Differentiating:
$$\frac{dA}{dt} = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}x\cdot\frac{dx}{dt}$$
At $x = 20$:
$$\frac{dA}{dt} = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\cdot 20 \cdot 2 = 20\sqrt{3} \text{ cm}^2/\text{s}$$

questions.question: Find: $\displaystyle\int (x+3)\sqrt{3-4x-x^2}\,dx$
questions.solution:
Write $x + 3 = -\dfrac{1}{2}(-4-2x) + 1$:
$$\int(x+3)\sqrt{3-4x-x^2}\,dx = -\frac{1}{2}\int(-4-2x)\sqrt{3-4x-x^2}\,dx + \int\sqrt{3-4x-x^2}\,dx$$
For the first integral, let $u = 3-4x-x^2$:
$$-\frac{1}{2}\int(-4-2x)\sqrt{u}\,du = -\frac{1}{3}(3-4x-x^2)^{3/2}$$
For the second integral, complete the square: $3-4x-x^2 = 7-(x+2)^2$:
$$\int\sqrt{7-(x+2)^2}\,dx = \frac{x+2}{2}\sqrt{3-4x-x^2} + \frac{7}{2}\sin^{-1}\!\left(\frac{x+2}{\sqrt{7}}\right)$$
Combining:
$$= -\frac{1}{3}(3-4x-x^2)^{3/2} + \frac{x+2}{2}\sqrt{3-4x-x^2} + \frac{7}{2}\sin^{-1}\!\left(\frac{x+2}{\sqrt{7}}\right) + C$$

questions.question:
Three schools A, B and C organized a mela for collecting funds for helping the rehabilitation of flood victims. They sold hand-made fans, mats and plates from recycled material at a cost of Rs. 25, Rs. 100, Rs. 50 each. The number of articles sold are given below:

| Article \ School | A | B | C |
|-----------------|---|---|---|
| Hand-fans | 40 | 25 | 35 |
| Mats | 50 | 40 | 50 |
| Plates | 20 | 30 | 40 |

Find the funds collected by each school separately by selling the above articles. Also find the total funds collected for the purpose. Write one value generated by the above situation.
questions.correctAnswer: School A: Rs. 7000; School B: Rs. 6125; School C: Rs. 7875; Total: Rs. 21000
questions.solution:
Setting up the matrix multiplication:
$$\begin{pmatrix} 40 & 50 & 20 \\ 25 & 40 & 30 \\ 35 & 50 & 40 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 25 \\ 100 \\ 50 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 7000 \\ 6125 \\ 7875 \end{pmatrix}$$
- Funds collected by school A: $40\times25 + 50\times100 + 20\times50 = 1000+5000+1000 =$ Rs. 7000
- Funds collected by school B: $25\times25 + 40\times100 + 30\times50 = 625+4000+1500 =$ Rs. 6125
- Funds collected by school C: $35\times25 + 50\times100 + 40\times50 = 875+5000+2000 =$ Rs. 7875

questions.question: If the function $f : \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}$ be given by $f(x) = x^2 + 2$ and $g : \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}$ be given by $g(x) = \dfrac{x}{x - 1}$, $x \neq 1$, find $fog$ and $gof$ and hence find $fog(2)$ and $gof(-3)$.

Prove that:
$$\tan^{-1}\!\left[\frac{\sqrt{1+x} - \sqrt{1-x}}{\sqrt{1+x} + \sqrt{1-x}}\right] = \frac{\pi}{4} - \frac{1}{2}\cos^{-1} x, \quad \frac{-1}{\sqrt{2}} \leq x \leq 1$$
questions.solution:
In LHS, put $x = \cos 2\theta$:

$$\tan^{-1}\!\left[\frac{\sqrt{1 + \cos 2\theta} - \sqrt{1 - \cos 2\theta}}{\sqrt{1 + \cos 2\theta} + \sqrt{1 - \cos 2\theta}}\right]$$

Using $1 + \cos 2\theta = 2\cos^2\theta$ and $1 - \cos 2\theta = 2\sin^2\theta$:

$$= \tan^{-1}\!\left[\frac{\sqrt{2\cos^2\theta} - \sqrt{2\sin^2\theta}}{\sqrt{2\cos^2\theta} + \sqrt{2\sin^2\theta}}\right] = \tan^{-1}\!\left[\frac{\cos\theta - \sin\theta}{\cos\theta + \sin\theta}\right]$$

$$= \tan^{-1}\!\left[\frac{1 - \tan\theta}{1 + \tan\theta}\right] = \tan^{-1}\!\left[\frac{\tan(\pi/4) - \tan\theta}{1 + \tan(\pi/4)\cdot\tan\theta}\right]$$

$$= \tan^{-1}\!\left[\tan\!\left(\frac{\pi}{4} - \theta\right)\right] = \frac{\pi}{4} - \theta$$

Since $x = \cos 2\theta \implies \theta = \dfrac{\cos^{-1} x}{2}$:

$$= \frac{\pi}{4} - \frac{1}{2}\cos^{-1} x = \text{RHS} \qquad \textbf{Proved}$$

alternativeQuestion.question: If $\tan^{-1}\!\left(\dfrac{x-2}{x-4}\right) + \tan^{-1}\!\left(\dfrac{x+2}{x+4}\right) = \dfrac{\pi}{4}$, find the value of $x$.
alternativeQuestion.solution:
$$\tan^{-1}\!\left(\frac{x-2}{x-4}\right) + \tan^{-1}\!\left(\frac{x+2}{x+4}\right) = \frac{\pi}{4}$$

Using the addition formula $\tan^{-1} A + \tan^{-1} B = \tan^{-1}\!\left(\dfrac{A+B}{1-AB}\right)$:

$$\tan^{-1}\!\left[\frac{\dfrac{x-2}{x-4} + \dfrac{x+2}{x+4}}{1 - \dfrac{x-2}{x-4} \cdot \dfrac{x+2}{x+4}}\right] = \frac{\pi}{4}$$

$$\implies \frac{(x-2)(x+4) + (x+2)(x-4)}{(x-4)(x+4) - (x-2)(x+2)} = 1$$

**Numerator:**
$$(x-2)(x+4) + (x+2)(x-4) = x^2 + 2x - 8 + x^2 - 2x - 8 = 2x^2 - 16$$

**Denominator:**
$$(x^2 - 16) - (x^2 - 4) = -12$$

$$\therefore \frac{2x^2 - 16}{-12} = 1 \implies 2x^2 - 16 = -12$$

$$\implies 2x^2 = 4 \implies x^2 = 2 \implies x = \pm\sqrt{2}$$

questions.question:
Using properties of determinants, prove that:

$$\begin{vmatrix} x+y & x & x \\ 5x+4y & 4x & 2x \\ 10x+8y & 8x & 3x \end{vmatrix} = x^3$$
questions.solution:
$$\text{LHS} = \begin{vmatrix} x+y & x & x \\ 5x+4y & 4x & 2x \\ 10x+8y & 8x & 3x \end{vmatrix}$$

Splitting the first column:

$$= \begin{vmatrix} x & x & x \\ 5x & 4x & 2x \\ 10x & 8x & 3x \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} y & x & x \\ 4y & 4x & 2x \\ 8y & 8x & 3x \end{vmatrix}$$

$$= x^3\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 5 & 4 & 2 \\ 10 & 8 & 3 \end{vmatrix} + yx^2\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 4 & 4 & 2 \\ 8 & 8 & 3 \end{vmatrix}$$

The second determinant has $C_1 = C_2$ after splitting, giving value $0$.

Applying $C_1 \to C_1 - C_2$ and $C_2 \to C_2 - C_3$ to the first determinant:

$$= x^3\begin{vmatrix} 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 2 & 2 \\ 2 & 5 & 3 \end{vmatrix} + 0$$

Expanding along $R_1$:

$$= x^3 \cdot 1 \cdot \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 2 & 5 \end{vmatrix} = x^3(5 - 4) = x^3 = \text{RHS} \qquad \textbf{Proved}$$

questions.question: Find the value of $\dfrac{dy}{dx}$ at $\theta = \dfrac{\pi}{4}$, if $x = ae^\theta(\sin\theta - \cos\theta)$ and $y = ae^\theta(\sin\theta + \cos\theta)$.
questions.solution:
Using parametric differentiation:
$$\frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{dy/d\theta}{dx/d\theta} \quad \cdots (1)$$

**Computing $\dfrac{dy}{d\theta}$** (using product rule):

$$\frac{dy}{d\theta} = ae^\theta(\cos\theta - \sin\theta) + ae^\theta(\sin\theta + \cos\theta) = 2ae^\theta\cos\theta$$

**Computing $\dfrac{dx}{d\theta}$:**

$$\frac{dx}{d\theta} = ae^\theta(\cos\theta + \sin\theta) + ae^\theta(\sin\theta - \cos\theta) = 2ae^\theta\sin\theta$$

Substituting into $(1)$:
$$\frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{2ae^\theta\cos\theta}{2ae^\theta\sin\theta} = \cot\theta$$

At $\theta = \dfrac{\pi}{4}$:
$$\left.\frac{dy}{dx}\right|_{\theta = \pi/4} = \cot\frac{\pi}{4} = 1$$

questions.question:
If $y = Pe^{ax} + Qe^{bx}$, show that:
$$\frac{d^2y}{dx^2} - (a+b)\frac{dy}{dx} + ab\,y = 0$$
questions.solution:
Given:
$$y = Pe^{ax} + Qe^{bx} \quad \cdots (1)$$

$$\frac{dy}{dx} = aPe^{ax} + bQe^{bx} \quad \cdots (2)$$

$$\frac{d^2y}{dx^2} = a^2Pe^{ax} + b^2Qe^{bx} \quad \cdots (3)$$

Multiplying $(1)$ by $ab$:
$$aby = abPe^{ax} + abQe^{bx} \quad \cdots (4)$$

Multiplying $(2)$ by $(a + b)$:
$$(a+b)\frac{dy}{dx} = (a+b)\left(aPe^{ax} + bQe^{bx}\right)$$
$$= \left(a^2Pe^{ax} + b^2Qe^{bx}\right) + \left(abPe^{ax} + abQe^{bx}\right) \quad \cdots (5)$$

Now computing $\dfrac{d^2y}{dx^2} - (a+b)\dfrac{dy}{dx} + aby$ using $(3)$, $(5)$, and $(4)$:

$$= \left(a^2Pe^{ax} + b^2Qe^{bx}\right) - \left[\left(a^2Pe^{ax} + b^2Qe^{bx}\right) + \left(abPe^{ax} + abQe^{bx}\right)\right] + \left(abPe^{ax} + abQe^{bx}\right)$$

$$= 0 \qquad \textbf{Proved}$$

alternativeQuestion.question: Find the equations of the tangent and normal to the curve $\dfrac{x^2}{a^2} - \dfrac{y^2}{b^2} = 1$ at the point $\left(\sqrt{2}\,a,\, b\right)$.
alternativeQuestion.correctAnswer: Tangent: $b\sqrt{2}\,x - ay - ab = 0$; Normal: $ax + b\sqrt{2}\,y - \sqrt{2}(a^2 + b^2) = 0$
alternativeQuestion.solution:
Given curve: $\dfrac{x^2}{a^2} - \dfrac{y^2}{b^2} = 1$

Differentiating implicitly:
$$\frac{2x}{a^2} - \frac{2y\,y'}{b^2} = 0 \implies y' = \frac{b^2 x}{a^2 y}$$

**Slope of tangent** at $(\sqrt{2}\,a, b)$:

$$y' = \frac{b^2 \cdot \sqrt{2}\,a}{a^2 \cdot b} = \frac{b\sqrt{2}}{a}$$

**Equation of Tangent** (using point-slope form):
$$y - b = \frac{b\sqrt{2}}{a}(x - \sqrt{2}\,a)$$
$$ay - ab = b\sqrt{2}\,x - 2ab$$
$$b\sqrt{2}\,x - ay - ab = 0$$

**Slope of Normal:**
$$m_{\text{normal}} = \frac{-1}{dy/dx} = \frac{-a}{b\sqrt{2}}$$

**Equation of Normal:**
$$y - b = \frac{-a}{b\sqrt{2}}(x - \sqrt{2}\,a)$$
$$yb\sqrt{2} - b^2\sqrt{2} = -ax + \sqrt{2}\,a^2$$
$$ax + b\sqrt{2}\,y - \sqrt{2}(a^2 + b^2) = 0$$

questions.question:
Evaluate:
$$\int_0^{\pi} \frac{4x\sin x}{1 + \cos^2 x}\, dx$$
questions.solution:
$$I = \int_0^{\pi} \frac{4x\sin x}{1 + \cos^2 x}\, dx$$

Applying the property $\displaystyle\int_0^a f(x)\,dx = \int_0^a f(a - x)\,dx$:

$$I = \int_0^{\pi} \frac{4(\pi - x)\sin(\pi - x)}{1 + \cos^2(\pi - x)}\, dx = \int_0^{\pi} \frac{4(\pi - x)\sin x}{1 + \cos^2 x}\, dx$$

Adding the two expressions:
$$2I = \int_0^{\pi} \frac{4\pi\sin x}{1 + \cos^2 x}\, dx$$

Using symmetry:
$$2I = 4\pi \cdot 2 \int_0^{\pi/2} \frac{\sin x}{1 + \cos^2 x}\, dx$$

$$I = 4\pi \int_0^{\pi/2} \frac{\sin x}{1 + \cos^2 x}\, dx$$

Put $\cos x = t \implies -\sin x\, dx = dt$

When $x = 0$, $t = 1$; when $x = \pi/2$, $t = 0$:

$$I = 4\pi \int_1^0 \frac{-dt}{1 + t^2} = 4\pi \int_0^1 \frac{dt}{1 + t^2}$$

$$= 4\pi\Big[\tan^{-1} t\Big]_0^1 = 4\pi\left[\tan^{-1} 1 - \tan^{-1} 0\right] = 4\pi \cdot \frac{\pi}{4} = \pi^2$$

alternativeQuestion.question:
Evaluate:
$$\int \frac{x + 2}{\sqrt{x^2 + 5x + 6}}\, dx$$
alternativeQuestion.solution:
$$\int \frac{x + 2}{\sqrt{x^2 + 5x + 6}}\, dx$$

Write $x + 2 = \lambda\dfrac{d}{dx}(x^2 + 5x + 6) + \mu = \lambda(2x + 5) + \mu$

Comparing coefficients:
- Coefficient of $x$: $1 = 2\lambda \implies \lambda = \dfrac{1}{2}$
- Constant term: $2 = 5\lambda + \mu \implies \mu = 2 - \dfrac{5}{2} = -\dfrac{1}{2}$

$$\therefore \int \frac{x+2}{\sqrt{x^2+5x+6}}\,dx = \int \frac{\frac{1}{2}(2x+5) - \frac{1}{2}}{\sqrt{x^2+5x+6}}\,dx = I_1 - I_2$$

**Computing $I_1$:**

$$I_1 = \frac{1}{2}\int \frac{2x+5}{\sqrt{x^2+5x+6}}\,dx$$

Put $x^2 + 5x + 6 = t \implies (2x+5)\,dx = dt$:

$$I_1 = \frac{1}{2}\int \frac{dt}{\sqrt{t}} = \sqrt{t} + C_1 = \sqrt{x^2+5x+6} + C_1$$

**Computing $I_2$:**

$$I_2 = \frac{1}{2}\int \frac{dx}{\sqrt{x^2+5x+6}} = \frac{1}{2}\int \frac{dx}{\sqrt{\left(x+\frac{5}{2}\right)^2 - \left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^2}}$$

$$= \frac{1}{2}\log\left[\left(x + \frac{5}{2}\right) + \sqrt{x^2 + 5x + 6}\right] + C_2$$

**Final Answer:**

$$I = \sqrt{x^2+5x+6} + \frac{1}{2}\log\left[\left(x + \frac{5}{2}\right) + \sqrt{x^2+5x+6}\right] + C$$

questions.question:
Find the particular solution of the differential equation:
$$\frac{dy}{dx} = 1 + x + y + xy$$
given that $y = 0$ when $x = 1$.
questions.solution:
$$\frac{dy}{dx} = (1 + x) + y(1 + x) = (1 + y)(1 + x)$$

Separating variables:
$$\frac{dy}{1 + y} = (1 + x)\,dx$$

Integrating both sides:
$$\int \frac{dy}{1 + y} = \int (1 + x)\,dx$$

$$\log|1 + y| = x + \frac{x^2}{2} + C$$

**Applying initial condition** $y = 0$ when $x = 1$:

$$\log|1| = 1 + \frac{1}{2} + C \implies 0 = \frac{3}{2} + C \implies C = -\frac{3}{2}$$

**Particular solution:**

$$\log|1 + y| = \frac{x^2}{2} + x - \frac{3}{2}$$

This can also be written as:
$$1 + y = e^{(x^2 + 2x - 3)/2} \implies y = e^{(x^2+2x-3)/2} - 1$$

questions.question:
Solve the differential equation:
$$(1 + x^2)\frac{dy}{dx} + y = e^{\tan^{-1} x}$$
questions.solution:
Rewriting in standard linear form:
$$\frac{dy}{dx} + \frac{y}{1 + x^2} = \frac{e^{\tan^{-1} x}}{1 + x^2}$$

Here $P(x) = \dfrac{1}{1+x^2}$ and $Q(x) = \dfrac{e^{\tan^{-1} x}}{1+x^2}$.

**Integrating Factor:**
$$IF = e^{\int P\,dx} = e^{\int \frac{1}{1+x^2}\,dx} = e^{\tan^{-1} x}$$

**General Solution:**
$$y \cdot e^{\tan^{-1} x} = \int e^{\tan^{-1} x} \cdot \frac{e^{\tan^{-1} x}}{1+x^2}\,dx + C$$

$$y \cdot e^{\tan^{-1} x} = \int \frac{\left(e^{\tan^{-1} x}\right)^2}{1+x^2}\,dx + C \quad \cdots (1)$$

To evaluate the integral, put $e^{\tan^{-1} x} = t$:

$$e^{\tan^{-1} x} \cdot \frac{1}{1+x^2}\,dx = dt$$

$$\therefore \int \frac{\left(e^{\tan^{-1} x}\right)^2}{1+x^2}\,dx = \int t\,dt = \frac{t^2}{2} + C = \frac{\left(e^{\tan^{-1} x}\right)^2}{2} + C$$

Substituting back into $(1)$:

$$y \cdot e^{\tan^{-1} x} = \frac{\left(e^{\tan^{-1} x}\right)^2}{2} + C$$

questions.question: Show that the four points A, B, C and D with position vectors $4\hat{i} + 5\hat{j} + \hat{k}$, $-\hat{j} - \hat{k}$, $3\hat{i} + 9\hat{j} + 4\hat{k}$ and $4(-\hat{i} + \hat{j} + \hat{k})$ respectively are coplanar.
questions.solution:
Given position vectors:
$$\vec{A} = 4\hat{i} + 5\hat{j} + \hat{k}, \quad \vec{B} = -\hat{j} - \hat{k}, \quad \vec{C} = 3\hat{i} + 9\hat{j} + 4\hat{k}, \quad \vec{D} = 4(-\hat{i} + \hat{j} + \hat{k})$$

Four points are coplanar if $\left[\overrightarrow{AB}\ \ \overrightarrow{AC}\ \ \overrightarrow{AD}\right] = 0$.

$$\overrightarrow{AB} = \vec{B} - \vec{A} = -4\hat{i} - 6\hat{j} - 2\hat{k}$$
$$\overrightarrow{AC} = \vec{C} - \vec{A} = -\hat{i} + 4\hat{j} + 3\hat{k}$$
$$\overrightarrow{AD} = \vec{D} - \vec{A} = -8\hat{i} - \hat{j} + 3\hat{k}$$

$$\left[\overrightarrow{AB}\ \overrightarrow{AC}\ \overrightarrow{AD}\right] = \begin{vmatrix} -4 & -6 & -2 \\ -1 & 4 & 3 \\ -8 & -1 & 3 \end{vmatrix}$$

Expanding along $R_1$:
$$= -4[12 + 3] + 6[-3 + 24] - 2[1 + 32]$$
$$= -4(15) + 6(21) - 2(33)$$
$$= -60 + 126 - 66 = 0$$

Since the scalar triple product is $0$, points A, B, C, D are **coplanar**. $\textbf{Proved}$

alternativeQuestion.question: The scalar product of the vector $\vec{a} = \hat{i} + \hat{j} + \hat{k}$ with a unit vector along the sum of vectors $\vec{b} = 2\hat{i} + 4\hat{j} - 5\hat{k}$ and $\vec{c} = \lambda\hat{i} + 2\hat{j} + 3\hat{k}$ is equal to one. Find the value of $\lambda$ and hence find the unit vector along $\vec{b} + \vec{c}$.
alternativeQuestion.solution:
$$\vec{b} + \vec{c} = (2 + \lambda)\hat{i} + 6\hat{j} - 2\hat{k}$$

Unit vector along $(\vec{b} + \vec{c})$:
$$\hat{u} = \frac{(2+\lambda)\hat{i} + 6\hat{j} - 2\hat{k}}{\sqrt{(2+\lambda)^2 + 36 + 4}} = \frac{(2+\lambda)\hat{i} + 6\hat{j} - 2\hat{k}}{\sqrt{(2+\lambda)^2 + 40}}$$

Given $\vec{a} \cdot \hat{u} = 1$:

$$\frac{(2+\lambda) + 6 - 2}{\sqrt{(2+\lambda)^2 + 40}} = 1$$

$$\implies (2 + \lambda + 4) = \sqrt{(2+\lambda)^2 + 40}$$

$$(\lambda + 6)^2 = (2+\lambda)^2 + 40$$

Squaring:
$$\lambda^2 + 12\lambda + 36 = \lambda^2 + 4\lambda + 4 + 40$$

$$8\lambda = 8 \implies \lambda = 1$$

With $\lambda = 1$:
$$\vec{b} + \vec{c} = 3\hat{i} + 6\hat{j} - 2\hat{k}$$

$$|\vec{b} + \vec{c}| = \sqrt{9 + 36 + 4} = 7$$

**Unit vector:**
$$\hat{u} = \frac{3\hat{i} + 6\hat{j} - 2\hat{k}}{7}$$

questions.question: An experiment succeeds thrice as often as it fails. Find the probability that in the next five trials, there will be at least 3 successes.
questions.solution:
Let $p$ = probability of success and $q$ = probability of failure.

Given: $p = 3q$ and $p + q = 1$:
$$3q + q = 1 \implies q = \frac{1}{4}, \quad p = \frac{3}{4}$$

Here $n = 5$. P(at least 3 successes) = P(X = 3) + P(X = 4) + P(X = 5):

$$P(X \geq 3) = \binom{5}{3}p^3q^2 + \binom{5}{4}p^4q^1 + \binom{5}{5}p^5$$

$$= \binom{5}{3}\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^3\!\!\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^2 + \binom{5}{4}\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^4\!\!\left(\frac{1}{4}\right) + \binom{5}{5}\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^5$$

$$= 10 \cdot \frac{27}{64} \cdot \frac{1}{16} + 5 \cdot \frac{81}{256} \cdot \frac{1}{4} + 1 \cdot \frac{243}{1024}$$

$$= \frac{3^5 + 5 \cdot 3^4 + 10 \cdot 3^3}{4^5} = \frac{3^3(9 + 15 + 10)}{1024} = \frac{27 \times 34}{1024} = \frac{459}{512}$$
